comments.author: bergmeister
comments.body:
For PowerShell Core, I have added the 'Run as Administrator' option. The feature in general is referred to as a jumpstart menu.
The implementation of it calls a very delicate and complex sequence of Windows COM APIs (in Windows PowerShell it is C++ code that can still be seen in the MainEntry.cpp file of the source-depot branch, in PowerShell Core it is managed C# code).
It works roughly like this: When PowerShell is starting up and the console host is detected to be interactive then it registers this jump start menu with Windows (if it is not already registered). As an aside: You can actually see this by pinning an icon of PowerShell (either Windows PowerShell or PSCore) to the taskbar in a fresh new VM and right-clicking on it and you will observe the jump start menu is not there, only after you have opened PowerShell the very first time, the jump start menu will appear from then on.

Without digging deep into the details of the Windows API calls, I cannot say with certainty whether it would be possible to register a startmenu for the Windows PowerShell binary from PowerShell Core (because I am sure the PowerShell team would be against changing code in Windows PowerShell), therefore one would need to research or PoC this.
If it is possible then there is the complication that if a jump start menu is registered and PowerShell Core is uninstalled (or re-installed using a different path), then the installer would need to clear it.

In the next months, I would like to re-review the complex implementation because at the time neither WPF nor the Windows API code pack had appropriate methods to make the required calls to the Windows API. I'd like to see how much of WPF is already open sourced in the upcoming .Net Core 3 Preview 6 or 7 and possibly make a PR there (once they are ready) so that the API can be simplified (I expect to simplify 600 lines of code to something like 10). After that it would be much simpler looking at this problem again without the need to dig very deep and write lots of code.
